poem:
Title: In the Wake of Cardboard Boats

Boxes laden, bubble-wrapped and corrugated,
vessels of wants sailing on guilt's sea.
Unveiling treasures wrapped in regret,
the new thing's thrill, fleeting as morning dew.
Excess whispers in cardboard echoes,
the hidden cost, a currency of consequence.
Even in silence, the footprint speaks.
In the wake of hollow abundance,
We become the custodians of our own undoing.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Every package carries a hidden cost’: is it better for the environment to shop online or in-store? Packages arrive at my house more than I’d like to admit. Whether they contain cosmetics, swimwear, T-shirts or socks, the sight of a brown cardboard box makes me feel two things: excitement for the new thing and guilt over its environmental impacts. Often the packaging feels excessive: boxes inside bigger boxes, things wrapped in bubble wrap or corrugated". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
